title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
TheoryPracticeSummary




Understanding Descriptive Statistics in Psychology
Descriptive statistics form the foundation of everything you will learn in this course.
They are the first tool psychologists use to make sense of data — whether the data come from questionnaires, experiments, observations, or clinical assessments.
Imagine you collect anxiety scores from 120 students before an exam. The raw numbers alone tell you very little. Some students are anxious, some are calm, some report very high values, and some surprisingly low ones. Without structure, these numbers remain a blur.
Descriptive statistics transform this blur into a clear, interpretable picture. They summarise what is typical, how much people vary, how scores are distributed, and how groups differ at a basic level. Before we can run any hypothesis test or make any interpretation, we need this descriptive picture.
Understanding descriptive statistics means understanding how psychological data “behave.”
It allows you to quickly recognise patterns, spot unusual values, and describe findings in a clear, scientific way.



Why These Methods Matter in Psychology
Psychology is a science that studies human behaviour, thoughts, and emotions. Humans differ enormously — in mood, personality, stress, performance, attention, and countless other ways. Even in a simple classroom sample, anxiety levels can vary widely.
Descriptive statistics help us answer fundamental questions:

How anxious is the average student?

How much do students differ from one another?

Is anxiety evenly distributed or skewed toward certain values?

Do students in a high-stress group tend to score higher than those in a low-stress group?

Without these answers, any later analysis would be built on uncertainty.
Well-performed descriptive analysis ensures that:

the data make sense,

values fall within reasonable ranges,

assumptions for later methods are not violated,

and results can be communicated clearly.

Before psychologists interpret patterns or make decisions, they always start with the descriptive layer.



From Raw Numbers to Meaning
When you first open a dataset, it may look something like this:
22, 18, 20, 25, 14, 31, 19, 23 …
This list is difficult to interpret. You might notice a few high values and a few low ones, but the overall structure is unclear.
Descriptive statistics help you translate these raw data points into meaningful statements, such as:

“Most students scored around 18–22.”

“A few scored below 10 or above 30.”

“The typical student reported moderate anxiety.”

“The distribution is fairly symmetric.”

“The low-stress and high-stress groups do not differ much.”

This translation from numbers to narrative is one of the most important skills in psychological research.



Levels of Measurement: Understanding the Variable First
Before summarising any psychological data, you must recognise what kind of variable you are working with. Different types of variables support different types of summaries and interpretations. Misunderstanding levels of measurement leads to incorrect conclusions — something professional researchers are trained to avoid.

Nominal Variables
Nominal variables consist of categories without an inherent order.
Examples:
- therapy type (CBT, ACT, psychodynamic),
- handedness,
- preferred coping style (“avoidance”, “problem-focused”, etc.)
We can count how many individuals fall into each category, but computing an average would be meaningless.


Ordinal Variables
Ordinal variables represent ordered categories, though the distances between categories are not guaranteed to be equal.
Examples:
- symptom severity (“none”, “mild”, “moderate”, “severe”),
- Likert scales (1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree)
We can say a score of 4 indicates “more agreement” than 2, but we cannot assume the jump from 1→2 equals the jump from 4→5.


Interval Variables
Interval variables have equal spacing between units, but no true zero.
Classic example: temperature in Celsius.
While rare in psychology, many psychological scales behave “almost interval-like,” which is why means and SDs are often used.


Ratio Variables
Ratio variables have equal spacing and a meaningful zero.
Examples in psychology:
- anxiety scores from 0–40,
- reaction time (0 ms = none),
- number of errors in a task,
- hours slept
Ratio variables allow all arithmetic operations and all descriptive methods.
Recognising the type of variable ensures correct interpretation and prevents misusing statistical tools.




Central Tendency: What Is Typical?
Every psychological variable has a centre — a typical value around which most scores cluster.
Understanding this “centre” helps you describe your sample accurately.

Mean
The mean (average) is calculated by adding all values and dividing by the number of observations.
It uses all available data and is widely used in research articles.
However, it is sensitive to outliers — a single extremely anxious student can shift the mean noticeably.


Median
The median is the middle value: half of the scores lie below it and half above it.
It is more robust against extreme values.
In skewed distributions (common in psychology), the median often gives a more truthful picture of central tendency.


Mode
The mode is the most frequently occurring value.
Useful especially for nominal variables.


Reading Mean vs. Median
Comparing the mean and median already tells a story:

mean ≈ median → roughly symmetric distribution

mean > median → distribution skewed to the right (a few very high values)

mean < median → distribution skewed to the left

Psychologists use this quick comparison before creating any graph.




Variability: How Much Do People Differ?
Two groups may share the same mean but differ dramatically in how spread out their scores are.
Variability is essential in psychology because individuals naturally differ — sometimes slightly, sometimes strongly.

Range
Simply the difference between the maximum and minimum values.
Easy to compute, but extremely sensitive to outliers.


Interquartile Range (IQR)
Captures the spread of the middle 50% of values.
This minimizes the influence of extreme scores and provides a robust sense of typical variability.


Standard Deviation (SD)
The most widely used measure of variability.
SD tells you the average distance between each value and the mean.
For example:
If the mean anxiety score is 20 and SD is 5, most students cluster roughly between 15 and 25.
High SD → a lot of variability
Low SD → individuals are relatively similar




Understanding the Shape of a Distribution
In addition to centre and spread, the shape of a distribution provides important psychological insight.
A distribution might be:

symmetric,

right-skewed (long tail to the right),

left-skewed,

bimodal (two peaks),

uniform (all values equally common).

Each pattern tells a story about the underlying psychological process.
For example:

A right-skewed distribution of anxiety might suggest that most students feel moderate anxiety, but a small group experiences very high stress.

A bimodal distribution of reaction times might suggest two types of strategies or two participant groups.

Being able to describe these shapes in words is a critical scientific skill.



Comparing Groups Descriptively
Much of psychology involves comparing groups:

treatment vs. control,

experienced vs. novice,

male vs. female,

low-stress vs. high-stress groups.

Descriptive statistics reveal:

whether one group tends to score higher or lower,

whether a group is more consistent or more variable,

whether extreme values appear in one group but not the other,

and whether simple differences exist even before conducting any formal test.

Before running t-tests or ANOVAs, psychologists always check these descriptive differences.
This helps avoid misinterpretations and ensures the data align with theoretical expectations.



The Foundation of All Later Statistical Concepts
Every advanced topic — probability, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, regression, ANOVA — builds directly on the descriptive concepts introduced here.
If you understand:

centres,

variability,

shapes,

and group comparisons,

then the rest of statistics becomes far easier.
Descriptive statistics are not merely the “first chapter.”
They are the core framework through which psychologists learn to read and interpret real human data.

title: Introductory Statistics for Psychology
text:
Welcome

Welcome to Introductory Statistics for Psychology. This website is designed as a calm, structured companion for your first steps into statistical thinking. It is not a formal university portal or an official institutional page; rather, it is a dedicated learning space created to support you as you move through the core ideas of statistics at your own pace. You can return to it whenever you need an explanation in simpler words, an example to anchor an abstract concept, or a visual summary to make sense of the bigger picture.
Many students begin their studies with mixed feelings about statistics. Some remember struggling with mathematics at school, some have not dealt with numbers for a long time, and others are simply unsure what statistics really means in the context of psychology. It is completely understandable to feel uncertain or even anxious at the beginning. This website explicitly acknowledges those feelings and is built for learners who may not see themselves as especially “mathematical.” You are not expected to understand everything immediately and you are not expected to like statistics from the very first moment. What matters is that you are willing to engage, to be curious, and to give yourself time.
Statistics in psychology is ultimately about making sense of data that come from people. When we measure stress, mood, memory performance, reaction times, social behaviour, or any other psychological construct, we obtain numbers that reflect real experiences and processes. These numbers do not speak for themselves. They need to be organised, summarised, and interpreted carefully. Statistical methods provide the language and tools for doing exactly that. They help us decide whether a pattern we see might be meaningful or whether it is more likely to have arisen by chance in a small sample. They allow us to connect individual observations to broader claims about groups and populations.
The aim of this resource is not to overload you with technical details, but to build a solid and intuitive understanding. New ideas are introduced in plain language first and only then connected to formal notation and calculations. The focus is on answers to questions such as what a concept means, why it is useful, what problem it solves, and how it behaves in simple psychological scenarios. If you move through the materials step by step, you will notice that topics which initially seemed complex start to feel more natural. Confidence in statistics does not appear all at once; it grows gradually as you encounter ideas from multiple angles and see how they connect.
You are invited to use this website actively rather than passively. Read the explanations, pause when something feels unclear, look at the examples, and then revisit earlier sections as needed. Statistics rewards repeated exposure. Each return strengthens connections in your understanding and makes it easier to see how individual pieces fit into a coherent whole. This site exists to support you in that process and to offer a stable point of orientation as you progress.



What This Course Will Teach You

The content presented here is structured around eight core topics that together form a continuous learning journey. You begin with descriptive statistics, where the essential vocabulary of data analysis is introduced. In this first topic you learn how to distinguish different types of variables, how to summarise what is typical in a dataset, how to quantify differences between individuals, and how to describe the shape of a distribution. You encounter ideas such as mean, median, mode, standard deviation, interquartile range, histograms, and boxplots. These ideas may look simple on the surface, yet they are fundamental to everything that follows.
Once you can describe data clearly, you are ready to think about uncertainty. The second topic introduces probability. Here you learn how to reason about events that may or may not occur, how to interpret statements about chances and risks, and how to understand concepts such as independence and conditional probability. Probability provides the conceptual bridge between what we see in a sample and what we want to say about a larger population. It helps you grasp why repeated sampling leads to patterns and why sometimes surprising outcomes can still be expected from a statistical point of view.
Building on this foundation, you move into tests and confidence intervals. In this part you see how statistical methods allow us to make structured claims about unknown quantities. You learn how to formulate hypotheses, how to measure the strength of evidence for or against them, and how to interpret a confidence interval as a range of plausible values rather than as a mystical object. The focus is on understanding what a test does and does not tell you and how conclusions always depend on assumptions and study design.
After learning how to make inferential statements, you turn toward relationships between variables. Covariance and correlation help you describe the degree to which two variables move together. You learn to recognise when a positive association, a negative association, or almost no association appears and how these patterns can inform psychological theories and practical questions. These ideas then open the door to regression, where you begin to model how one variable can be predicted from another.
In simple linear regression, you explore models with a single predictor and see how a straight line can summarise the relationship between two variables. You learn how to interpret the slope and intercept and what it means when a model fits data well or poorly. This naturally extends to partial correlations and multiple regression, where several predictors are considered simultaneously. These topics are particularly important in psychology because many outcomes of interest are influenced by a combination of factors. Understanding how to work with such models helps you think more realistically about complex behaviour and mental processes.
Finally, you encounter analysis of variance, often abbreviated as ANOVA. Here you learn how to compare means across more than two groups in a coherent framework and how to understand variability as something that can be partitioned into meaningful components. This ties back to earlier ideas about variance and standard deviation and shows you how descriptive and inferential concepts interact. By the time you reach this point, you will see that the eight topics are not isolated islands but parts of a connected landscape of ideas.
The intention is that, by moving through all eight topics, you develop not only technical skills but also a deeper sense of how statistics supports psychological research and informed critical thinking. You should come away with an ability to read results, to question them intelligently, and to understand in broad terms what different analyses are doing.



How to Use This Website

Each topic page on this site is built around three core elements: theory, practice, and summary visuals. These elements are meant to work together and to give you multiple ways of approaching the same underlying ideas. The theory sections provide detailed explanations in continuous text. They aim to be as clear and concrete as possible, using psychological examples and everyday language to explain why a concept matters and how it behaves. When you read these sections, it can be helpful to imagine how the ideas would apply to situations you care about, such as understanding stress, learning, relationships, or mental health.
The practice sections then show you how the concepts appear when you analyse actual data. You will see realistic datasets, R code, and graphical outputs. The goal is not that you memorise every line of code, but that you develop a sense of what typical analyses look like. Over time, patterns will become familiar: you will recognise how data are loaded, how variables are summarised, how distributions are visualised, and how group comparisons are made. You can use these practice sections as guided examples and, if you wish, as starting points to experiment with your own variations.
The summary visuals provide a different kind of access to the material. They condense the main ideas of each topic into carefully designed images that you can revisit quickly. When you are preparing for an exam, working on exercises, or revising a concept you have not seen for a while, these visuals can serve as compact reminders of the structure of the topic. A good learning strategy is to read the theory, work through the practice, and then use the summary visual to check whether you can explain each element of the image in your own words. If something feels vague, you can go back to the relevant section and strengthen that link.
You do not have to move through all topics strictly in a linear fashion. It is often useful to follow the intended order the first time, because later topics assume familiarity with earlier ones. At the same time, you are encouraged to revisit earlier pages whenever a new concept feels difficult. Many ideas in statistics are interconnected. A more solid understanding of descriptive statistics, for example, can make probability and inference easier to grasp. Similarly, a clearer view of variability can make regression models feel less abstract. This website is meant to be a place you move through repeatedly, not a one-time checklist.
If you ever feel stuck, it can help to slow down and focus on a single example rather than the general case. You might take one dataset from the practice section and ask yourself what you would say about it in everyday language before looking at any formulas. Often, translating back and forth between intuitive statements and formal tools is where the deepest learning happens. The materials here are designed to support exactly that type of thinking.



Begin With Topic 1

If this is your first visit, start with Topic 1 on descriptive statistics. In that topic you will learn how to recognise the different levels of measurement, how to describe what is typical in a dataset, how to quantify spread, and how to talk about the overall shape of a distribution. You will see how even simple summaries such as the mean, median, and standard deviation can tell a rich story about the underlying psychological process that generated the data. You will also see how visualisations like histograms and boxplots can reveal patterns that are not obvious from a table of numbers.
Spending time with these foundations is one of the most valuable investments you can make in your statistical education. Almost every analysis you will encounter later, whether in this resource or in other courses, begins with or should begin with a careful descriptive examination of the data. When you are comfortable interpreting simple summaries and graphs, more complex techniques become far easier to understand. They become natural extensions of ideas you already know rather than entirely new obstacles.
As you move beyond the first topic into probability, inference, correlations, regression, and ANOVA, try to keep a sense of continuity. Each new concept is a response to a question that arises naturally from what came before. Probability answers questions about uncertainty that appear when we look at variable data. Tests and confidence intervals formalise how we decide whether an observed effect might reflect something real. Correlation and regression answer questions about how variables change together. ANOVA responds to the challenge of comparing several groups at once. Seeing the course as a sequence of questions and answers can help keep motivation alive and make the material feel more meaningful.
This website is here to accompany you throughout that journey. You can read it slowly or quickly, alone or alongside lectures and exercises. You can approach it when you feel confident and want to deepen your understanding, and you can also return when you feel unsure and need to rebuild your foundations. Wherever you are starting from, it is possible to grow more comfortable and more skilled with statistics than you might expect.
Welcome to your statistics journey. Let us begin.

title: Descriptive Statistics
section: Understanding Exactly What Kind of Variable You Are Dealing With
text:
Understanding Exactly What Kind of Variable You Are Dealing With
Before you calculate anything — mean, median, SD, correlation, anything — you must first know:

What kind of variable is this?

Why?
Because not all variables allow the same operations.
Some variables allow you to calculate means.
Others do not.
Some variables allow mathematical comparisons.
Others only allow counting.
This is one of the most common misunderstandings for beginners — and one of the easiest ways to make incorrect conclusions in psychological research.
Let’s start at absolute zero.

title: Descriptive Statistics
section: Describing the “Typical” Value in a Psychological Sample
text:
Describing the “Typical” Value in a Psychological Sample
After understanding what kind of variable you have, the next question is:
Where do most people fall?
Psychology is full of statements like:

“On average, patients improved.”

“Typical daily stress levels were moderate.”

“Most children scored within the normal range.”

These statements rely on central tendency.

Mean
Add everything, divide by the number of people.
Highly informative but sensitive to outliers.
Example:
If one participant has an extremely high depression score, the mean will shift upward.


Median
The middle score.
Perfect for skewed distributions, like income, stress, or symptoms.
Example:
If most students have low depression scores but one has a very high one, the median barely changes.


Mode
The most frequent value.
Especially useful for categorical variables (e.g., most common diagnosis).


Reading psychological meaning
Mean ≈ median → symmetric distribution (common in cognitive tasks)
Mean > median → right-skewed (common in anxiety, reaction times)
Mean < median → left-skewed (less common, sometimes in speeded tasks)
Understanding these patterns allows you to describe data professionally.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
How Much Do People Differ?
Central tendency is only half of the story.
Psychology is fundamentally interested in individual differences.
Two therapy groups might have identical average depression levels:
both at 20.
But if one group ranges from 5 to 35 and the other from 18 to 22, the psychological interpretation is completely different.

Range
Quick sense of spread, but influenced entirely by two values.


IQR (Interquartile Range)
Describes the middle 50% of people.
Very stable even with outliers.


Standard Deviation
The most widely used.
Tells you how typical deviations from the mean are.
In many psychological variables:

SD ≈ 1/4 of the scale width = moderate variability

SD ≈ 1/2 of the scale width = high variability

Understanding variability is essential for interpreting experiments, questionnaires, and clinical outcomes.

title: Descriptive Statistics
section: Why It Matters for Psychological Interpretation
text:
Why It Matters for Psychological Interpretation
Two samples can have the same mean and SD but completely different shapes.
Typical patterns in psychology:

Right-skewed
(e.g., anxiety, depression, reaction times)
Most people score low/moderate, a few score very high.


Bimodal
(e.g., two groups using two different strategies on a cognitive task)
Two peaks suggest subgroups.


Uniform
(rare in psychology)
All values equally common.
Knowing the shape helps you:

choose correct statistics,

interpret outliers,

avoid incorrect assumptions,

and accurately describe what the data look like.

title: Descriptive Statistics
section: The Professional Flow of Psychological Analysis
text:
The Professional Flow of Psychological Analysis
In psychological research, you always:

Describe both groups clearly
(“The high-stress group had slightly higher anxiety but similar variability.”)
Check for unusual patterns
(e.g., outliers, skewness)
Then perform inferential statistics
(t-test, ANOVA, regression, etc.)

You cannot skip step 1.
If you do, you risk misinterpreting your results.
Descriptive statistics protect you from incorrect conclusions and allow you to communicate your findings confidently and transparently.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Nominal Level
Nominal variables contain categories that have no inherent order — they simply label groups.
Examples include:

therapy type (CBT, ACT, psychodynamic)

coping style categories

handedness
type of emotion being expressed (anger, joy, fear)

diagnosis categories

These categories tell us which group someone belongs to, not how much of something they have.

What summaries make sense?
We can meaningfully compute:

counts (“How many people responded with each option?”)

proportions (“What percentage chose each category?”)



What is not meaningful?
An average would be meaningless because averaging categories implies numerical distance where none exists.
If three participants prefer “CBT,” “ACT,” and “psychodynamic,” the “average” of these three labels has no psychological interpretation. There is no quantity we can interpolate between “CBT” and “ACT.” A category is a name, not a number.
This is why nominal data are never summarised with means, medians, or SDs. They do not represent numerical magnitude.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Ordinal Level
Ordinal variables represent ordered categories, but the spacing between categories is not guaranteed to be equal.
Examples:

Likert ratings (1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree)

symptom severity (“mild,” “moderate,” “severe”)

ranking tasks (“1st”, “2nd”, “3rd”)

perceived stress levels on a 3-point scale

These variables tell us relative order — who has more or less of something — but they do not guarantee equal distance between levels.
A jump from “moderate” to “severe” does not necessarily equal the jump from “mild” to “moderate.” Similarly, the psychological distance between “agree” and “strongly agree” might not match the distance between “neutral” and “agree.”

What summaries make sense?

medians

percentiles

rank-based statistics

ordered bar charts



What about means?
Psychologists often report means for Likert scales, but this is a matter of convention rather than strict mathematics. The mean can be used if you interpret it cautiously and understand its limitations.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Interval Level
Interval variables have:

equal spacing between units, and

no true zero.

A classical example is temperature measured in Celsius or Fahrenheit.
In some psychological contexts, variables behave approximately interval-like, even if not perfectly: for instance, a 0–100 scale measuring subjective well-being, where each point is designed to represent an equal step.
Because spacing is assumed to be equal, we can compute:

means

standard deviations

correlations

z-scores


Why does “no true zero” matter?
Because without a true zero, ratios become meaningless. For example, 20°C is not “twice as warm” as 10°C — the zero point is arbitrary.
Thus, interval data support many operations, but not ratio statements.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Ratio Level
Ratio variables are the most informative type. They have:

equal spacing, and

a meaningful zero that represents the total absence of the quantity.

Examples include:

reaction time (0 ms means no time elapsed)

number of correct answers

hours slept

anxiety symptoms counted on a 0–40 scale

Because zero means “none,” ratios become meaningful:

A reaction time of 600 ms is twice as long as 300 ms.

A score of 20 symptoms represents twice the number of symptoms as a score of 10.

Ratio variables allow all descriptive measures:

mean

median

SD

IQR

correlations

ratios

comparisons of magnitude

This is why many psychological measurements aim, when possible, to approximate a ratio scale.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Summary

Descriptive statistics give the essential overview needed before deeper analysis:

centre — where values tend to lie

spread — how much individuals differ

shape — whether data are symmetric or skewed

comparison — whether groups differ descriptively

These tools allow students to interpret questionnaire scores, reaction times, clinical scales, and behavioural data with clarity.
